segments.text: A few topics that I would like to talk about, various things actually.
A couple days ago I was talking about the importance of selective attention.
By that I mean that when you define an object of meditation, which could be narrow or it
could be broad, you mercilessly become uninterested to the best of your ability in everything
else.
So often people will ask me, it's just amazing, I'll give them the defined object of meditation
to be like, stay with the images, right?
And then they'll ask me, what should I do when the talk comes up?
What should I do when the body sensations come up?
Because there is a tendency when you focus on one thing for the competing things to get
activated.
Well, here's how I would put it.
To the best of your ability, ignore it.
That doesn't mean suppress it.
That doesn't mean think you failed if it arises.
It simply means try to not be interested in it, number one.
And number two, when you find that you are pulled away, gently return to whatever your
defined object of focus is.
One thing that can be useful in doing that is to remember that when a so-called distraction
arises, it can have exactly one of three effects on the thing that you're focusing on.
The first effect is that it may stimulate it.
Your object of meditation is the flow of mental images, and you hear there's a bunch of sounds
going on around you.
Each of those sounds may stimulate a mental image.
So then you stay with your object of meditation by watching that stimulating effect or by
being aware of that stimulating effect.
That's possibility number one.
Possibility number two is that the arising of the competing phenomenon may deactivate
the thing that you're looking at.
In other words, it may cause it to become lesser or to slow down or to dissolve or to
stop.
Be aware of that effect.
Typically, I will give you categories like clear, subtle, none.
And I'll say now, if you have clear internal talk, say clear.
If there's dead silence, say none.
And if it's anything in between, say subtle.
And then there's dead silence from them for three minutes.
And then I say, what's been happening during the silence?
And they say, well, I can't find any talk yet.
What should they have been saying?
None, none, none.
That's why those categories were given.
In general, I will give you categories that are exhaustive and non-valenced.
So let me explain what I mean.
These are terms from logic.
Exhaustive means that they exhaust all possibilities.
Whatever happens must fall within those categories.
And non-valenced is that there's no agenda, no preference.
No preference that it be one versus the other.
No preference that you get all of them to happen during an individual session.
That's what I mean by non-valence.
There's no valence or value attached to one versus the other.
Some of the noting categories, in addition to being exhaustive and non-valenced, are
exclusive.
That is to say, they evenly partition the set of possibilities and there's no overlap.
Sometimes the categories overlap.
They don't exclude each other.
It doesn't matter whether the categories overlap or are non-overlapping, are exclusive, as
long as they're exhaustive and non-valence.
In art, they have what's called negative space, which means that artists train themselves
to look as keenly for the absence of things as they do for the presence.
That's called negative space.
So the zeros in your computer are as important as the ones.
You can't store data just with ones.
You store data with yes and no, both.
So when you're paying attention to a phenomenon, being aware that it is not arising is something
to be aware of.
And that's an important part of the sort of data flow or information.
So as I say, if you're selectively attending to a certain aspect of experience and a competing
experience arises, if it stimulates the thing that you are selectively attending to, then
be aware of that stimulation.
If it causes it to diminish or even disappear, then be aware of that.
The third possibility, of course, is that a competing event will have no impact whatsoever
on the thing that you're observing.
Often, this is rather subtle, but I'll just share it with you to sensitize you to this
phenomenon.
Often just when you get distracted from the thing you're observing is when the thing you're
observing starts to melt into impermanence.
But unfortunately, you're already distracted into something else, so the insight doesn't

Basically, what happens is that you're not fixating the thing anymore because you're
about to get interested in something else.
So because there's no craving and aversion in it, it shows you its essential waveform.
But it doesn't do any good because you're already looking in another direction.
So I'll just share that with you, that when you feel that pulse of distraction, I've seen
this happen now so many times that as soon as I feel distraction, I start to get fascinated
with the impermanence in the thing I'm trying to focus on, because it's starting to loosen
up and flow, I'd say probably half the time.
And that now helps me to keep with my original object of focus.
Yes?
So when you sense that you're being distracted, do you on purpose focus on what you were focusing
on?
You pull yourself back, that's right.
Basically you try to become disinterested in the distractions, number one.
You try to observe the impact of the distraction on the thing that you're working with.
If there is such an impact, that's number two.
And number three, when you get carried away and you lose it, you come back.
Is there anything to come back to, though, by the time you get back?
Well, usually, yeah.
It may have become subtle or something like that, but if your object is body sensations

That's very good, actually.
Actually there are two levels of focus in the vipassana practice.
Both are important and you learn from both.
One level of focus is you're focusing on a phenomenon.
You're trying to get flavor, you know, location, whatever.
The second level of focus is you're focusing on the impermanence of the phenomenon, how

In general, if you can focus on the impermanence of the phenomenon, that's, quote, better because

So if you are able to focus on the impermanence, then that's good.
That's not a distraction.
That's an insight into the nature of it.
And then basically what happens is that at some point the impermanence meditates you.
You don't meditate on it.
It becomes you, it starts to eat you up, to digest you, to pull you into it.

Now related to this theme, I would like to clarify two ways that the labeling process
is used.
Either of these ways of labeling is fine, but I think it is absolutely essential that
you understand the difference and that you understand which you are doing.
First of all, what do I mean by labeling?
Usually the first technique involving labeling that I teach people is to free float inside
the body and label the sensations by location.
Then a lot of people think that's labeling.
That's one kind of labeling.
That is one way to label one aspect of experience.
You can label body sensation by quality, by intensity level, or by primary location, or
by whether the impact is local, global, or both.
There's many different ways you can label body sensation, and that's just body sensation.
You can label the thinking process in terms of the content of thought.
A lot of vipassana teachers teach that.
You label your thoughts as memory, plan, fantasy, judgment, and so forth.
Personally, I like to label the thoughts in terms of the basic sense mode involved, talk,
image, or both.
So the point I'm making is that labeling is a generic process.
Any aspect of experience that can be broken up into categories that are exhaustive and
non-valenced can be labeled.
The labels can be said out loud.
They can be said to yourself, or you can drop the labels and just be aware of the categories.
There's even a way of labeling digitally, assigning labels to fingers, and pressing
or not pressing, depending on the patterns of experience.
But there are two ways that the labels are used.
The traditional Burmese way, which comes from the Mahasi Sayadaw lineage, is that whatever
you label, you are attempting to, quote, penetrate.
That means you label things that are your object of meditation, that are facets of what
you are focusing on.
And when you label it, you attempt for that moment to have a complete experience of it.
So everything that is labeled is equal to everything else that is labeled in terms of
your interest.
The second way to use labels is very prevalent in the West.
And it's fine, but it's different.
In the second way that labels are used, you actually have two categories of labels.
One, you label your object of focus.
For example, let's say your object of focus is the rising and falling of your abdomen
as you're sitting.
And so you go rising, falling, rising, falling to yourself.
Then when a sound comes up or a feeling tone or a thought, you say sound, feeling, thought.
But when you say that, you're not attempting to focus on that sound or feeling or thought.
You're not attempting to penetrate it, to experience in that moment its essential impermanence.
What you are in essence saying is, that's just a sound, now get back to the breath.
That's just a thought, now get back to the breath.
You're using the label in this case as a dismissing sound, and then you go back to the breath.
Do you understand the difference?
No, that's the one that most Westerners do.
The traditional Burmese, as I understand it, is what you label, you penetrate.
So you can use the labels either way.
Just be very clear as to which one you're doing.
Any questions about that?
The reason I'm so emphatic is that I've never seen this issue really addressed in the Western
Buddhist literature.
Yes?
So you're labeling dismissively rather than ignoring.
Well labeling dismissively is sort of a way to help you ignore.
You're reporting on the distraction.
Yes, that's right.
But you're not attempting to include that in your object.
That's one way that the labels are used.
For me myself, I don't like doing that, but a lot of people find that useful.
For me, what I label is I penetrate whatever I label, whether it's a broad categorization

So I just wanted to say those sort of some clarifying remarks apropos of the process

with the object of focus and so forth.
Yes?
Your object of meditation is talk, image, feel.
Yes.

Exactly correct.
Yes?

If there's something you're returning to, it's simply talk, image, and feel as opposed

For me.
Okay?

When you look at the brain, in between the thalamus, which is in essence the reptilian
